qas.question: What was the support by voters for referendum?

answers.text: Muslim Brotherhood and some liberal and secular activist groups

context: On <a0_0>18 January 2014<a0_0/>, the interim government instituted a new constitution following a referendum in which <a1_0>98.1%<a1_0/> of voters were supportive. Participation was low with only 38.6% of registered voters participating although this was higher than the 33% who voted in a referendum during Morsi's tenure. On 26 March 2014 <a2_0>Abdel Fattah el-Sisi<a2_0/> the head of the Egyptian Armed Forces, who at this time was in control of the country, resigned from the military, announcing he would stand as a candidate in the 2014 presidential election. The poll, held between 26 and 28 May 2014, resulted in a landslide victory for el-Sisi. Sisi was sworn into office as President of Egypt on 8 June 2014. The <a3_0>Muslim Brotherhood and some liberal and secular activist groups<a3_0/> boycotted the vote. Even though the military-backed authorities extended voting to a third day, the 46% turnout was lower than the 52% turnout in the 2012 election.
